Accessed 2011-01-27.) is a British [[statistician]]. His research interests include [[multivariate statistics]], [[statistical classification|classification methods]], [[pattern recognition]], the [[computational statistics]] and the [[foundations of statistics]].{{cite web|url=http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/people/d.j.hand|title=Professor David Hand|publisher=[[Imperial College London]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}} He has written books on finance, measurement and computation in statistics, as well as authoring the ''[[Very Short Introductions|Very Short Introduction]]'' to statistics. Hand was a professor of statistics at the [[Open University]] from 1988 until 1999, when he moved to [[Imperial College London]]. He was awarded the [[Guy Medal]] in Silver by the [[Royal Statistical Society]] in 2002 and served as its President in 2008â€“9, then again from in 2010 after [[Bernard Silverman]] stood down.{{cite web|url=http://www.rss.org.uk/site/cms/contentviewarticle.asp?article=486|title=Past President|accessdate=2011-01-27|publisher= The [[Royal Statistical Society]].}} He was elected a [[Fellow of the British Academy]] in 2003. Hand's book ''The Improbability Principle: Why Coincidences, Miracles, and Rare Events Happen Every Day'' was published by Scientific American in February 2014. Hand was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2013 New Year Honours]] for services to research and innovation.{{LondonGazette |issue=60367 |date=29 December 2012 |startpage=11 |supp=yes }}{{cite web | url = http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/sites/default/files/resources/NY2013-list.pdf | title = New Year Honours List 2013 - General List | publisher = Cabinet Office | accessdate = 29 December 2012}} ==Selected works== ===Books=== * 2001.
